questions.question: A sprinter accelerates from rest to a velocity of $9.5\,\text{m/s}$ over a distance of $18\,\text{m}$. Assuming constant acceleration, calculate the magnitude of the sprinter's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Using the kinematic equation $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$ with $u = 0\,\text{m/s}$, $v = 9.5\,\text{m/s}$, and $s = 18\,\text{m}$, we have $9.5^2 = 2a(18) \Rightarrow a = 90.25/36 \approx 2.51\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A jet lands on an aircraft carrier at a speed of $65\,\text{m/s}$ and is brought to a complete stop by an arresting gear in $2.1\,\text{s}$. Determine the acceleration of the jet (assume constant).
questions.explanation: Acceleration is given by $a = (v - u)/t$, where $u = 65\,\text{m/s}$, $v = 0\,\text{m/s}$, and $t = 2.1\,\text{s}$. Thus $a = (0-65)/2.1 \approx -31.0\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A stone is thrown vertically downward from the top of a $45\,\text{m}$ tall building with an initial speed of $5.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the speed of the stone just before it hits the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)

An arrow is shot straight up into the air and remains in flight for a total of $7.4\,\text{s}$ before returning to the launch point. Determine the initial launch velocity. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: The time to reach maximum height is half the total flight time: $t_{\text{up}} = 7.4/2 = 3.7\,\text{s}$. Initial velocity $u = gt = 9.8(3.7) \approx 36.3\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A soccer ball is kicked from the ground with an initial velocity of $25\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Calculate the time it takes to reach its peak height. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: The vertical component of initial velocity is $v_{y0} = 25\sin30^\circ = 25(0.5) = 12.5\,\text{m/s}$. Time to peak $t = v_{y0}/g = 12.5/9.8 \approx 1.28\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A rescue plane flying horizontally at $40\,\text{m/s}$ at an altitude of $120\,\text{m}$ drops a package. Calculate the horizontal distance the package travels from the drop point before hitting the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{240/9.8} \approx \sqrt{24.49} \approx 4.95\,\text{s}$. Horizontal range $= v_x \times t = 40 \times 4.95 \approx 198\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ and reaches a maximum height of $15\,\text{m}$. Calculate the initial launch speed. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: At maximum height, $v_y = 0$. Using $0 = (v_0\sin45^\circ)^2 - 2gh$, we have $v_0^2(0.5) = 2(9.8)(15) = 294$. Thus $v_0^2 = 588$ and $v_0 = \sqrt{588} \approx 24.2\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A boat heads due North across a river at $4.0\,\text{m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows due East at $3.0\,\text{m/s}$. Determine the magnitude of the velocity of the boat relative to a stationary observer on the shore.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular, so the resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{(4.0)^2 + (3.0)^2} = \sqrt{16 + 9} = \sqrt{25} = 5.0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels South at $80\,\text{km/h}$ and Car B travels South at $105\,\text{km/h}$. Determine the velocity of Car B relative to Car A.
questions.explanation: Relative velocity $\vec{v}_{B/A} = \vec{v}_B - \vec{v}_A$. Both velocities are South, so $v_{B/A} = 105 - 80 = 25\,\text{km/h}$ directed South.

questions.question: A $40\,\text{kg}$ sled is pulled across a level snow surface by a horizontal force of $60\,\text{N}$. If the sled accelerates at $0.8\,\text{m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the sled and the snow. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Net force $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 40(0.8) = 32\,\text{N}$. Frictional force $f_k = 60 - 32 = 28\,\text{N}$. Normal force $N = mg = 392\,\text{N}$. Thus $\mu_k = f_k/N = 28/392 \approx 0.071$.

questions.question: A $1500\,\text{kg}$ truck requires a braking force of $6000\,\text{N}$ to stop. If it was traveling at $22\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the distance required to come to a complete stop (assuming constant braking force).
questions.explanation: Deceleration $a = -F/m = -6000/1500 = -4.0\,\text{m/s}^2$. Using $v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a\Delta x$ with $v=0$, we have $0 = 22^2 + 2(-4)\Delta x \Rightarrow \Delta x = 484/8 = 60.5\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A constant horizontal force of $120\,\text{N}$ is applied to a $30\,\text{kg}$ object on a frictionless surface. If the object starts from rest, calculate its displacement after $4.0\,\text{s}$.
A $20\,\text{kg}$ trunk is placed on a ramp inclined at $15^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the normal force acting on the trunk. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The normal force is $N = mg\cos\theta = 20(9.8)\cos15^\circ = 196(0.9659) \approx 189.3\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A block is released from rest at the top of a $5.0\,\text{m}$ long frictionless ramp inclined at $40^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. Calculate the speed of the block at the bottom of the ramp. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The vertical height of the ramp is $h = L\sin\theta = 5.0\sin40^\circ \approx 5.0(0.6428) = 3.21\,\text{m}$. By conservation of energy, $v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2(9.8)(3.21)} = \sqrt{62.916} \approx 7.94\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Two masses, $12\,\text{kg}$ and $18\,\text{kg}$, are suspended over a frictionless pulley by a light string. Determine the acceleration of the system when released from rest. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)

A $6.0\,\text{kg}$ mass sits on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.2$. It is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $4.0\,\text{kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the connecting string. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: For the system: $m_2g - \mu m_1g = (m_1 + m_2)a \Rightarrow 4(9.8) - 0.2(6)(9.8) = 10a \Rightarrow 39.2 - 11.76 = 27.44 = 10a \Rightarrow a \approx 2.744\,\text{m/s}^2$. For the hanging mass: $m_2g - T = m_2a \Rightarrow T = 4(9.8 - 2.744) = 4(7.056) \approx 28.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $0.5\,\text{kg}$ object is suspended from a spring scale in an elevator moving upward at a constant velocity of $3.0\,\text{m/s}$. What is the reading on the scale? (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero acceleration, so the scale reading equals the weight: $N = mg = 0.5(9.8) = 4.9\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $25\,\text{kg}$ sign is supported by two cables. One cable pulls horizontally, and the other pulls at an angle of $50^{\circ}$ to the vertical. Calculate the tension in the angled cable. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: From vertical force equilibrium: $T\cos50^\circ = mg = 245\,\text{N}$. Thus $T = 245/\cos50^\circ \approx 245/0.6428 \approx 381\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A centrifuge rotates at a rate of $3000\,\text{RPM}$. If the radius is $10\,\text{cm}$, calculate the tangential speed of a sample located at the outer edge.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity $\omega = 3000 \times 2\pi/60 = 100\pi\,\text{rad/s}$. Tangential speed $v = \omega r = 100\pi \times 0.10 = 10\pi \approx 31.4\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A satellite orbits a planet at a constant speed of $7500\,\text{m/s}$. If the orbital radius is $8.0 \times 10^6\,\text{m}$, calculate the time required for one complete orbit (the orbital period).
questions.explanation: The orbital period is $T = 2\pi r/v = 2\pi(8.0\times10^6)/7500 \approx 50.27\times10^6/7500 \approx 6702\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A pilot of mass $80\,\text{kg}$ pulls out of a dive by following a circular arc of radius $500\,\text{m}$ at a speed of $150\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the normal force exerted by the seat on the pilot at the bottom of the arc. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the net inward force (centripetal) is $N - mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $N = mg + mv^2/r = 80(9.8) + 80(150^2)/500 = 784 + 80(22500)/500 = 784 + 80(45) = 784 + 3600 = 4384\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A bucket of water is whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.2\,\text{m}$. What is the maximum period of rotation allowed to ensure that the water does not fall out at the top of the circle? (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Minimum speed at the top to maintain circular motion: $v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 1.2} = \sqrt{11.76} \approx 3.43\,\text{m/s}$. Period $T = 2\pi r/v = 2\pi(1.2)/3.43 \approx 7.54/3.43 \approx 2.19\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A $0.15\,\text{kg}$ puck is attached to a string and moves in a horizontal circle of radius $0.6\,\text{m}$ on a frictionless table. If it completes $2$ revolutions per second, calculate the tension in the string.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity $\omega = 2(2\pi) = 4\pi\,\text{rad/s}$. Tension provides centripetal force: $T = m\omega^2 r = 0.15(4\pi)^2(0.6) = 0.15(16\pi^2)(0.6) = 0.15(9.6\pi^2) = 1.44\pi^2 \approx 14.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the necessary banking angle for a highway curve of radius $200\,\text{m}$ so that a car traveling at $25\,\text{m/s}$ requires no friction to stay on the road. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: For ideal banking, $\tan\theta = v^2/(rg) = 25^2/(200 \times 9.8) = 625/1960 \approx 0.319$. Thus $\theta = \arctan(0.319) \approx 17.7^{\circ}$.

questions.question: The Moon has a mass of $7.35 \times 10^{22}\,\text{kg}$ and a radius of $1.74 \times 10^6\,\text{m}$. Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on the Moon's surface. (Take $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$)
Two objects experience a gravitational force of magnitude $F$. If the mass of one object is doubled and the distance between them is halved, what is the new gravitational force in terms of $F$?
questions.explanation: Newton's law: $F \propto m_1 m_2 / r^2$. New force $F' \propto (2m_1) m_2 / (r/2)^2 = 2m_1 m_2 / (r^2/4) = 8(m_1 m_2 / r^2) = 8F$.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car skids to a stop over a distance of $35\,\text{m}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the tires and the road is $0.7$, calculate the work done by friction on the car. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Frictional force $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.7(1200)(9.8) = 8232\,\text{N}$. Work done by friction $W = -f_k d = -8232 \times 35 = -288,120\,\text{J} \approx -288\,\text{kJ}$.

questions.question: A $0.5\,\text{kg}$ ball traveling at $10\,\text{m/s}$ is caught, bringing it to rest over a distance of $0.2\,\text{m}$. Calculate the average force exerted by the hand on the ball.
questions.explanation: Work done by the hand equals the change in kinetic energy: $W = \Delta KE = 0 - \frac{1}{2}(0.5)(10)^2 = -25\,\text{J}$. Since $W = -Fd$, we have $F = 25/0.2 = 125\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: An archer pulls back a bowstring with an average force of $140\,\text{N}$ over a distance of $0.6\,\text{m}$. Calculate the speed of a $0.03\,\text{kg}$ arrow as it leaves the bow.
questions.explanation: Work done on the arrow $W = Fd = 140 \times 0.6 = 84\,\text{J}$. This becomes kinetic energy: $\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 84 \Rightarrow v = \sqrt{2(84)/0.03} = \sqrt{168/0.03} = \sqrt{5600} \approx 74.8\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ block is pushed against a horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 500\,\text{N/m}$, compressing it by $0.2\,\text{m}$. If the block is released and moves across a horizontal surface with $\mu_k = 0.1$, how far will it travel before stopping? (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy stored: $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(500)(0.04) = 10\,\text{J}$. Frictional force $f = \mu_k mg = 0.1(2)(9.8) = 1.96\,\text{N}$. Work by friction equals energy dissipated: $fd = E \Rightarrow d = 10/1.96 \approx 5.10\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A roller coaster car of mass $500\,\text{kg}$ is at the top of a $40\,\text{m}$ high hill moving with a speed of $4.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate its kinetic energy at the bottom of the hill if $15,000\,\text{J}$ of energy is lost to friction and air resistance. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Initial total mechanical energy: $E_i = KE_i + PE_i = \frac{1}{2}(500)(4.0)^2 + 500(9.8)(40) = 4000 + 196,000 = 200,000\,\text{J}$. Energy at bottom: $E_f = E_i - 15,000 = 185,000\,\text{J}$, which is all kinetic energy.

questions.question: A $1000\,\text{kg}$ elevator is lifted vertically at a constant speed of $2\,\text{m/s}$ over a distance of $20\,\text{m}$ in $10\,\text{s}$. Calculate the power required by the motor to lift the elevator. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Work done against gravity: $W = mgh = 1000(9.8)(20) = 196,000\,\text{J}$. Power $P = W/t = 196,000/10 = 19,600\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A car experiences a constant resistive force of $600\,\text{N}$ while moving. If the engine provides $30\,\text{kW}$ of power, calculate the maximum constant speed the car can maintain.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, power $P = Fv$, where $F$ is the force opposing motion. Thus $v = P/F = 30,000/600 = 50\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A bungee cord behaves like a spring with spring constant $k = 40\,\text{N/m}$. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored in the cord when it is stretched $15\,\text{m}$ beyond its natural length.
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(40)(15)^2 = 20 \times 225 = 4500\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: Two identical springs are connected in series. If each spring has a stiffness of $k$, determine the equivalent stiffness of the combination.
questions.explanation: For springs in series, the reciprocal of the equivalent stiffness is the sum of the reciprocals: $1/k_{eq} = 1/k + 1/k = 2/k$, so $k_{eq} = k/2$.

questions.question: A $2000\,\text{kg}$ truck moving at $10\,\text{m/s}$ rear-ends a $1000\,\text{kg}$ car that is stopped at a traffic light. If they lock bumpers and move together, calculate the velocity of the wreck immediately after impact.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f$. Thus $2000(10) + 1000(0) = 3000v_f \Rightarrow v_f = 20,000/3000 \approx 6.67\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.1\,\text{kg}$ bouncy ball is dropped from a height of $2.0\,\text{m}$ and rebounds to a height of $1.8\,\text{m}$. Calculate the percentage of kinetic energy lost during the collision with the floor. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Initial potential energy $\propto 2.0\,\text{m}$, final potential energy after rebound $\propto 1.8\,\text{m}$. Energy lost fraction $= (2.0 - 1.8)/2.0 = 0.1 = 10\%$.

questions.question: A $0.05\,\text{kg}$ bullet is fired from a $4.0\,\text{kg}$ rifle. If the bullet exits the barrel with a velocity of $400\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the recoil velocity of the rifle (neglect external forces).
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_b v_b + m_r v_r \Rightarrow v_r = - (m_b v_b)/m_r = - (0.05 \times 400)/4.0 = -20/4 = -5.0\,\text{m/s}$. The magnitude is $5.0\,\text{m/s}$ in the opposite direction.

questions.question: Three identical resistors are connected in series. If the total power dissipation is $12\,\text{W}$ when connected to a $6\,\text{V}$ source, calculate the resistance of a single resistor.
questions.explanation: Total power $P = V^2/R_{\text{total}} \Rightarrow R_{\text{total}} = V^2/P = 36/12 = 3\,\Omega$. For three identical resistors in series, $R_{\text{total}} = 3R$, so $R = 1\,\Omega$.

questions.question: In a series circuit, three resistors have values $R_1 = 4\,\Omega$, $R_2 = 6\,\Omega$, and $R_3 = 10\,\Omega$. If the voltage drop across $R_2$ is $3.0\,\text{V}$, calculate the battery voltage.
questions.explanation: Current $I = V_2/R_2 = 3.0/6 = 0.5\,\text{A}$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 4 + 6 + 10 = 20\,\Omega$. Battery voltage $V = IR_{\text{total}} = 0.5 \times 20 = 10\,\text{V}$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $10\,\Omega$, a $20\,\Omega$, and a $100\,\Omega$ resistor when all are connected in parallel.
A parallel circuit has two branches. Branch 1 carries a current of $10\,\text{A}$. If Branch 2 has double the resistance of Branch 1, calculate the current in Branch 2.
questions.explanation: In parallel, voltage is the same across each branch: $I_1 R_1 = I_2 R_2$. Given $R_2 = 2R_1$, we have $10R_1 = I_2(2R_1) \Rightarrow I_2 = 5\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination consisting of a $6\,\Omega$ and a $3\,\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of the circuit.
questions.explanation: For the $6\,\Omega$ and $3\,\Omega$ in parallel: $R_p = (6 \times 3)/(6 + 3) = 18/9 = 2\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 12 + 2 = 14\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A $9\,\text{V}$ battery is connected to a $3\,\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $6\,\Omega$ resistors. Find the power dissipated by the $3\,\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Two $6\,\Omega$ in parallel give $R_p = 3\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 3 + 3 = 6\,\Omega$. Current $I = 9/6 = 1.5\,\text{A}$. Power in $3\,\Omega$ resistor: $P = I^2R = (1.5)^2(3) = 2.25 \times 3 = 6.75\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: The tension in a string is doubled while all other factors remain constant. By what factor does the speed of a transverse wave on that string change?
questions.explanation: Wave speed on a string is $v = \sqrt{T/\mu}$, where $T$ is tension and $\mu$ is linear mass density. If tension becomes $2T$, new speed $v' = \sqrt{2T/\mu} = \sqrt{2} \times \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{2}v$.

questions.question: A wave pulse travels a distance of $10\,\text{m}$ in $2.0\,\text{s}$. If the frequency of the wave source is $20\,\text{Hz}$, determine the wavelength of the wave.
questions.explanation: Wave speed $v = \text{distance}/\text{time} = 10/2.0 = 5\,\text{m/s}$. Using $v = f\lambda$, we get $\lambda = v/f = 5/20 = 0.25\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A source of sound emits a frequency of $600\,\text{Hz}$. If the source moves away from a stationary observer at $20\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the frequency heard by the observer. (Assume the speed of sound is $340\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: Using the Doppler effect formula for a moving source receding from a stationary observer: $f' = f \left( \frac{v}{v + v_s} \right) = 600 \left( \frac{340}{340 + 20} \right) = 600 \left( \frac{340}{360} \right) = 600 \times 17/18 \approx 567\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Define the condition for the third 'node' (point of destructive interference) in terms of the path difference and wavelength $\lambda$.
questions.explanation: Destructive interference occurs when the path difference is an odd multiple of half-wavelengths: $(n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. For the third node, $n=2$, so path difference $= (2 + \frac{1}{2})\lambda = \frac{5}{2}\lambda$.

questions.question: An open-ended organ pipe has a length of $0.75\,\text{m}$. Calculate the frequency of the fundamental harmonic produced by this pipe. (Assume the speed of sound is $344\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental wavelength is $\lambda = 2L = 2 \times 0.75 = 1.5\,\text{m}$. The fundamental frequency is $f = v/\lambda = 344/1.5 \approx 229\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies $256\,\text{Hz}$ and $260\,\text{Hz}$ are played simultaneously. Calculate the beat frequency heard by an observer.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference of the two frequencies: $f_{\text{beat}} = |f_1 - f_2| = |260 - 256| = 4\,\text{Hz}$.
